captions.text:
• From wallpaper cleaner turned into a children's
toy to laughing gas that nobody knew could

stop you from feeling pain, we count 15 innovative
creations created by the craziest of accidents

15 - Potato Chips,
• A creation that only became reality when

a chef in upstate New York called George Crum
had a customer continually sending back his

plate of fried potatoes, claiming they weren't
satisfactory

• George got so fed up that he thinly sliced
the potatoes and deep fried them until they

were crispy - simply to spite the customer,
but in a bizarre twist, the customer LOVED

the potato chips and asked for more
• After that, potato chips suddenly became

a huge thing in the snack industry, simply
because a chef was pissed off at an annoying

customer
14 - Corn Flakes,

• 1984, the Kellogg brothers ran a hospital
and health spa in Michigan in which they advised

clients to abstain from meat, alcohol, tobacco
and a whole manner of things deemed unhealthy

at the time
• They substituted caffeine in coffee with

granola, and one day when cooking some wheat
they were called away only to come back and

find the wheat stale - but they still put
it through the rollers

• Out came wheat berry flattened into thin
flakes, paving the way for the cereal we know

today as corn flakes
• Later the company would shy away from

the "healthy" breakfast line-up to focus on
outdoing the sugar-filled competition with

Honeycomb and Waffle Crisp Corn Flake flavours
13 - Play-Doh,

• It was originally a wallpaper cleaner,
a successful one at that, but after people

stopped using coal to heat their homes in
the mid-20th century, wallpaper stayed clean

• The owner of the company quickly though
up an alternative to their product with help

from his sister-in-law - to market it as modelling
clay for children

• They took out the detergent ingredient,
added a pleasant scent and a variety of colours

and Play-Doh became what we know today
12 - Chocolate Chip Cookies,

• 1930, a woman was baking a chocolate dessert
when she realised she'd run out of traditional

chocolate - to substitute, she dumped in Nestle
chocolate chips

• To her shock, the chocolate chips didn't
melt into the cookie, but stayed relatively

solid - her initial disappointment gave way
a few years later when Nestle offered a deal

to use her company name in a line of the world's
first chocolate chip cookies known as Semi-Sweet

Chocolate Morsels
• The recipe went on to become a staple

in restaurants and kitchens across the globe
11 - Velcro,

• 1950s, A Swiss man named George de Mestral
walking through the countryside, annoyed that

those little sticky plants known as cockleburs
were all over his clothes

• He got home and took out a microscope
only to find these things actually had microscopic

hooks which latched onto the fabric of his
clothes

• He then took this information and devised
a material that might be used to keep things

easily stuck together without adhesive or
tightness - hence the idea of Velcro was born

10 - X-Rays,
• In the era of developing knowledge on

invisible rays such as radio waves and radiation,
one physicist discovered that when he pumped

electricity through a special light bulb tube,
a chemical a few feet away would glow

• He realised that the tube was sending
out invisible rays that could penetrate paper,

wood and even skin - he called them X-Rays,
the "x" meaning "unknown"

• The first x-ray image was of the bone
in his wife's hand, and upon viewing the image,

she cried out "I have seen my own death"
9 - Penicillin,

• Before this discovery and the age of anti-biotics,
common illnesses were rampant and lethal - the

average life expectancy was hardly above the
age of 50

• In 1928. Alexander Fleming left town for
a while and came back to find his petri dishes

were full of mould and contamination
• One container drew his eye though - though

it was covered in bacteria, in one area was
a blob of mould - around the mould, an area

free of bacteria as if the mould were blocking
it from approaching

• The contents of this petri dish could
be used to kill a huge amount of bacteria

- hence the discovery of penicillin
8 - Plastic,

• If it weren't for two accidents, it's
possible we'd be using clay and eggs mixed

with animal blood as a water bottle
• But Charles Goodyear of Goodyear Tires

combined rubber and sulfur and accidentally
placed it on a stove - where it merged to

form a strong and durable material we know
today as plastic

• Whereas in an unrelated incident, in a
contest to find a replacement for elephant

ivory in billiard balls, John Wesley Hyatt
spilled a bottle of collodion where it dried

up to form plastic
• By the year 1872, his creation became

the first commercially successful plastic
7 - Super Glue,

• A researcher at Kodak called Harry Coover
experimenting with plastic lenses for gun

sights when he stumbled on an extra sticky
adhesive made from synthetic materials

• He thought nothing of it at the time,
but almost 10 years later one of his assistants

rediscovered it while accidentally sticking
a couple of prisms together

• Harry realised the market potential, so
he decided to take it further and commercialise

it, the title: Super Glue
6 - Anaesthesia,

• We're all thankful for this one, the so-called
"laughing gas" used to inhibit pain during

surgery - it was in the 1800s that inhaling
the gas was more of a social event referred

to as a "laughing party" or "ether frolic"
• In 1844, Horace Wells saw a man with an

injured leg while under the influence of the
laughing gas, to which the man claimed he

didn't feel any pain
• Following this, Horace used the gas to

help him remove a tooth, to which he and some
colleagues realised they could use in the

wider field of dentistry
• Over the years it took off and became

a staple of the medical industry
5 - Tea,

• A very old recipe from thousands of years
ago which, if legend would have us believe,

saw a Chinese emperor named Shennong boiling
his drinking water in a cauldron

• One windy day some leaves from a nearby
tea bush blew into the water without his knowledge

and turned it a light brown
• Most would tip out the water and start

again, but since Shennong understood herbalism
he decided to risk a taste, only to discover

it tasted nice - and thus tea became a thing
4 - Matches,

• For 10s of thousands of years starting
a fire has always been a chore, but in 1826

John Walker discovered a curious recipe for
a strikable 3-inch long match

• He was stirring a pot of chemicals when
a dried lump formed at the end of the mixing

stick, and when he tried to scrape it off,
it ignited

• He sold miniature versions of them at
his local bookstore, but because he hadn't

patented the idea someone else came along
to steal the idea - eventually these "friction

sticks" became the safety matches we know
today

3 - Viagra,
• Two researchers at a pharmacy were experimenting

with a new drug they hoped would treat high
blood pressure and heart disease, and in the

late 1980s they moved on to human trials
• Though the drug wasn't effect, the side

effects lead them down an entirely different
industry - most of the test subjects reported

they got massive erections that wouldn't go
away

• A new clinical trial was conducted, this
time with the aim to treat erectile dysfunction,

and in 1998 viagra was finally approved by
the U.S Food and Drug Administration

2 - Ice Cream Cone,
• This is a widely accepted mystery - during

the late 1800s, street vendors couldn't decide
on what container they should use for ice-cream,

whether it be paper, glass or metal
• In 1902, two people filed patent for edible

bowls for their ice-cream, but it was in 1904
at the World's Fair that ice-cream quickly

sold out, the waffle stands weren't doing
so good so they started combining the two

to increase sales
• Wrapping up waffles and putting ice cream

on top - after the fair, hundreds of people
all applied for the patent all at once, but

nobody truly knows who was the first one
1 - Microwave Oven

• Percy Spencer, an engineer at Raytheon
was doing radar research with a vacuum tube

when he noticed something melting in his pocket
• His candy bar seemed to be cooking where

he stood - so Percy decided to test this notion
of invisible waves cooking food by throwing

in some popcorn kernels
• Every one of them popped, the idea was

miniaturised and placed in pretty much every
kitchen around the world

comments.author: Felix Karlzen

comments.text:
+Moon Kowalski it actually is powerful enough, though.

However, in the experiment, it clearly wasn't. Don't forget that chocolate 
melts at body temperature. 

A microwave works differently from an oven. It cooks from the inside out 
instead of the outside in, like a conventional oven does. 

The warmth nerves are a little bit beneath the surface of our skin. Great 
at sensing warmth from the air and the outside world, but they can't sense 
a rise in body temperature. 

If anything, the scientist would feel cold since the room temperature 
dropped relative to his body (which actually rose in temperature). He might 
even have felt a bit feverish, but this is more than enough to melt 
chocolate.

+Red Med not in, but on one.
Old stoves heated the entire piece of furniture (both the inside and the 
top, since the rest was usually isolated with ceramics) because it all came 
from one heat source, which was either cole or wood burning in one 
compartment.

They were usually left on to warm up the house.

He probably placed those things on top of the stove while he had to do 
something else, like open a door, after which he just forgot about it.

comments.author: singingfrog

comments.text:
+singingfrog I just looked it up (Thank God for the Internet) In 1894 Dr. 
John Harvey Kellogg was superintendent of a famous hospital and health spa 
in Battle Creek, Michigan. His younger brother, Will Keith Kellogg, was the 
business manager. The hospital stressed healthful living and kept its 
patients on a diet that eliminated caffeine, meat, alcohol, and tobacco. 
The brothers invented many foods that were made from grains, including a 
coffee substitute and a type of granola, which they forced through rollers 
and rolled into long sheets of dough. One day, after cooking some wheat, 
the men were called away. When they finally returned, the wheat had become 
stale. They decided to force the tempered grain through the rollers anyway.

Surprisingly, the grain did not come out in long sheets of dough. Instead 
each wheat berry was flattened and came out as a thin flake. The brothers 
baked the flakes and were delighted with their new invention. They realized 
they had discovered a new and delicious cereal, but they had no way of 
knowing they had accidentally invented a whole new industry. Will Keith 
Kellogg eventually opened his own cereal business, and its most famous 
product is still sold today:
It wasn’t until 1906 that Kellogg’s® Corn Flakes were made available to the 
general public. In 1909, the very first cereal premium was offered: The 
Funny Jungleland Moving Pictures Booklet available with the purchase of 2 
packages. The offer was available for twenty-three years!
T

comments.text:
Two other stories I heard about the microwave, 1) Two military engineers 
during the Cold War were adjusting an microwave antenna that was attempting 
to launch missiles at the moon due to misalignment.  One of the engineers 
mysteriously started coughing up blood and died, an autopsy showed he had 
been roasted medium-rare.  The antenna was built by Raytheon.  2) An 
engineer that worked on it was Linda Ronstadt's grandfather.﻿

Cookies themselves were also created by accident. Cooks used a small amount 
of cake batter to test their oven temperature before baking a large cake.

Dutch. They weren't meant to be eaten but were discovered to taste nicely.﻿
